title: calmac launches mobile maintenance team
story: CalMac continues to work with Transport Scotland to find new flexible and effective approaches to address the ongoing challenges of operating an ageing fleet with an increasing number of sailings.The seven-strong team comprises electrical and mechanical engineers, along with hydraulic specialists.The team will be tasked with carrying out planned maintenance to vessels in-service, as well as being a flexible resource that can be deployed immediately to support on-board engineers with any technical issues.Last year CalMac’s -strong fleet carried more than . million passengers and . million vehicles across  islands and remote mainland locations, including Campbeltown, in some of western Europe’s most inhospitable waters. This represents more than , sailings last year.‘We are operating with an ageing fleet which is increasingly being stretched,# said CalMac managing director Robbie Drummond. #We need to continue to find new ways to maximise our vessels# operational resilience and have invested in a new team that will help mitigate potential problems before they escalate into something that impacts on service delivery.#The team will carry out specialised inspections, monitoring and proactive maintenance, working closely with the on-board engineering and vessel management teams to proactively identy and resolve technical issues.The aim is to minimise service disruptions due to avoidable technical issues and reduce the routine maintenance that would normally take place during annual overhaul.‘With our vessels setting sail around  times every day, this team has the mobility required to complete planned maintenance when and where it is needed on the network, minimising disruption to services due to technical issues,’ added Robbie.Councillor John Armour, chairman of the Campbeltown ferry committee, told the Courier: #Anything that stops problems arising or speeds up repairs on the ferries is very welcome.#

title: campbeltown school is crumbling

My colleagues and I have been invited to visit and found the condition to be disgraceful.#Our children are coming up to the st century in terms of education standards but the building is living in the th century.#Can somebody apply pressure to look at schools in Campbeltown and find some programme for a revamp #Councillor Kieron Green, Oban North and Lorn, deputy chairman of the council’s community services committee, responded: #There is a process the council has to go through. title: treasurer-embezzled-thousands-of-pounds-from-community-charity
story: Brian Smith was in charge of the finances at Cockenzie House and Gardens for less than a year when he began siphoning off pound, from the charityrsquos bank account.Smith, , used the stolen cash to pay for his day-to-day living expenses.Smithrsquos callous scam went unnoticed for about six months until it began to unravel and he went into his local police station and confessed all in April last year.The Cockenzie-based charity has described the theft as ldquoa devastating blow and said the non-profit organisation was just days from closing down due to Smithrsquos deceit.He has now been ordered to pay the massive sum back to the charity through a compensation order and been placed on supervision for eight months following an appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court last week.Smith, of Old Course Gate, Musselburgh, was also ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work in the community.The court was told that Smithrsquos home has been repossessed due to the mortgage not being paid and he will be in a position to pay all the cash back to the charity within six months.Sherf Donald Corke told Smith he had ldquocynically and greedily drained the charityrsquos bank account and had left ldquofinancial chaos in his wake.The sherf added: ldquoYou have pled guilty at the first opportunity to embezzling pound, from the charity. You were a voluntary treasurer at that time and it was a gross breach of trust.ldquoYou cynically and greedily drained the charityrsquos money and spent it on your own household expenses.Smith had previously pleaded guilty to the embezzlement charge when defending solicitor Mary Moultrie revealed her client had gone to the police and handed himself in.Smith, a former used car salesman, became involved with the charity in  after his we had rented an art studio within Cockenzie House.The father-of-two soon became treasurer after helping to overhaul the charityrsquos IT system but within months he was pilfering cash from its bank account.It is believed that Smith racked up about pound, in debt in the charityrsquos name after he failed to pay rent and utility bills over the period he acted as treasurer.A spokesperson for the charity said: ldquoThis has been a very dficult and challenging time for Cockenzie House and Gardens as we have lost half of our annual turnover through this embezzlement.Despite this devastating blow, the trustees are proud to say we have managed to make a good recovery and our focus now is to continue to build a sustainable future for the charity.Smith pleaded guilty to embezzling pound, while treasurer of Cockenzie House and Gardens between May , , and April  last year.

title: lorry-driver-told-to-get-out-and-take-a-kicking-from-irate-motorist
story: Alexander McLeod drove on the wrong side of the road and pulled up in front of the large truck before getting out of his car and demanding driver Colin Holmes fight with him.McLeod shouted, ldquoYou f***ing a***hole at the man. He then yelled: ldquoGet out, Irsquom going to give you a kicking during the incident at Willowbrae Road, Edinburgh.McLeod, of Suthren Yett, claimed that the truck driver had collided with his car and driven away moments before he decided to chase after the lorry.The -year-old building firm owner appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where he admitted two charges committed during the road rage incident.Solicitor Colm Dempsey told the court that his client had four children and employed two full-time workers at his building firm.Mr Dempsey said that McLeod had become irate after a piece of plant machinery on the back of the truck had struck McLeodrsquos car as they both negotiated road works at Willowbrae.He said McLeod thought the driver had failed to notice the collision and then ldquomade the stupid decision to stop in front of the vehicle.Mr Dempsey said that the damage to his clientrsquos car had been about pound, and admitted: ldquoHe is too old to be behaving like this.The solicitor pleaded with Sherf John Cook not to ban McLeod, who already had six penalty points on his licence, from driving as this would affect his livelihood.Sherf Cook agreed and sentenced McLeod to a pound, fine and placed five penalty points on his licence.McLeod admitted driving on the opposite carriageway, bringing a vehicle to a halt and causing it to perform an emergency stop at Willowbrae Road, Edinburgh, on October  last year. He also pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by shouting, swearing and challenging Colin Holmes to fight during the same incident.

title: plans-lodged-for-new-a1-sliproad-at-queen-margaret-university
story: The changes to the road are being carried out to allow major development surrounding Queen Margaret Universityat Musselburgh to go ahead.Currently the only way to get to the university from the A is from the eastbound carriageway, heading from Edinburgh into East Lothian.The new slip roadswill create an access and exit route on the westbound carriageway, with a new underpass built beneath the main road and new roundabout built to the west of it.Drawings of the proposals have been lodged by the council with itsown planning department.The application states that the proposals will ldquocomplete a junction commenced in  through planning approval that was to access land used for agriculture which could be developed affording opportunities for employment land.More than  hectaresof land around the university, straddling the A, has been given the go-ahead for a major mixed use development.As well as , new homes, there are proposals for an innovation hub connected to the universityitself, business and commercial spaces, a primary school and public spaces.It is anticipated that the innovation hub could create up to , new jobs in the area and it has secured funding from the Edinburgh and South East of Scotland City Deal.However, it has been accepted that the new development will need upgrades to the access points from the A, leading to the plans being lodged.The cost and timescale of the new project is unclear. The council said: ldquoUntil due planning process is complete, we cannot advise on costs and timescales.Barry Turner, of Musselburgh Conservation Society, said: ldquoThis proposal is an essential development of this junction, enabling direct access to QMU and the proposed business park from the east.ldquoIt also opens up the area to the south of the A for development, though the conservation society would prefer to see this area left as open fields.

title: youngsters-dress-up-as-campie-primary-school-celebrates-centenary
story: Two days of celebrations were enjoyed, including the opportunity for people from the community to tour the school, view an exhibition of photos and memorabilia, and share their Campie memories.Ahead of the celebrations, children explored the schoolrsquos past, present and future in their learning, with the number  featuring in work around science, technology, engineering and maths.The festivities also featured a party in the playground, while teachers and children were able to dress up in costume from any decade in the last century.A school spokesperson said: ldquoWe had a wonderful celebration.ldquoThe school looked wonderful and everyone who came thoroughly enjoyed looking at old photos, sharing memories and meeting up with old friends and colleagues.ldquoMany of our children and staff dressed up on the Friday and there was such a happy feeling in the school. Thanks to everyone who donated photos and memorabilia, and who contributed in any way to our th birthday.Ward councillor Andy Forrest said: ldquoI would like to congratulate Campie on its th birthday. This is a fantastic achievement and it is a credit to the community, the level of support that has been given to the school.ldquoI would also like to thank staff past and present for the work put in by them to ensure there is a welcoming, friendly learning facility.The school opened on May , , with  pupils under the stewardship of headteacher Thomas Brown. Today, the school of  pupils is led by Pauline McKay and her team.The building at Stoneyhill Farm Road has been extended over the years, most recently in , to accommodate the growing school community.

title: car-club-withdraws-from-haddington-and-north-berwick
story: Co-wheels, the UKrsquos biggest car club, has withdrawn from the two towns from Saturday due to low usage levels.Members had been able to hire a Toyota Yaris based at Haddingtonrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre, a Toyota Aygo at North Berwickrsquos Glebe Car Park and a Renault Zoe EV at North Berwickrsquos Imperial Car Park.Tony Archer, Scottish location manager at Co-wheels, said: ldquoWe have decided to re-locate the Co-wheels cars in Haddington and North Berwick to alternative Scottish locations due to a greater demand of the car club where in the country. This will take effect from June . Registered members who have utilised the Haddington and North Berwick cars have been notied and we hope they will continue to use the Co-wheels car club service in other locations in the future.Co-wheels ndash which has been operating in East Lothian for more than six years ndash also has a Toyota Yaris hybrid based at Dunbar Railway Station and a Toyota Aygo X-Play Nav at the townrsquos Bleachingfield Centre, as well as a Toyota Yaris Hybrid at Bridge Street in Musselburgh and a Toyota Aygo X-Play Nav located on the townrsquos High Street.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, said: ldquoI am disappointed that Co-wheels has not managed to make a success of this very interesting venture. I understand there are other car clubs starting to look at setting up in East Lothian and will be interested to how this develops.His view was echoed by Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillor Tom Trotter, who was surprised by the news.He said: ldquoThat is sad. I had not heard anything in the build up to that it has come right out of the blue. I donrsquot know how much they were getting used but it is a service for people.Co-wheels is a pay-as-you-go car hire scheme where members can book cars online and use a smartcard to access them ndash no need for keys. At the end of the booking, members, who only pay for the hire time and distance they drive,the car to a dedicated parking bay.

title: mary-poppins-nursery-in-athelstaneford-to-close-this-summer
story: Mary Poppins Nursery in Athelstaneford has announced that its last day will be Friday, August , blaming the impact of the extension of funded hours by the Scottish Government for its impending closure.Owner Ruth Dewar said: ldquoThe decision was a very painful one.ldquoIn the past two years, it has been increasingly dficult to continue as a viable business. There are several factors influencing this, but the major factor which has tipped the balance is the extended funding hours and the negative impact this is having both financially on small businesses, like Mary Poppins, and to the quality of early learning and childcare.New Scottish Government policy instructs councils to increase their funded childcare hours from  to , by . This move also includes longer opening hours and a move from term time to year-round opening hours to attempt to make childcare more nationally accessible.Ms Dewar said: ldquoThe money received for funded places does not cover the costs of providing the quality of early learning and childcare which we want and are required to provide, especially with regards to staff costs.ldquoThe timescales and measures that the Scottish Government has put in place to educate a workforce to meet the increased requirements are insufficient, and there is a serious shortfall to meet the requirements of the extended funding.ldquoEast Lothian Council indicated it estimated it would require approximately  staff to facilitate the increase in funded hours in East Lothian. The majority of these posts are early learning and childcare practitioners.ldquoThe local authority advertises early learning practitioner posts at between pound. and pound. per hour. Private nurseries are unable to compete with these rates of pay due to the funding rates we are allocated.A group of parents and staff, including Ms Dewar, are visiting county MSP Iain Gray to discuss the problems, but Ms Dewar added that unless he can ldquowork a miracle and change the policy, then it is unlikely the decision to close the nursery will be reversed.When asked about the nursery, Mr Gray said: ldquoThe loss of any nursery provision is disappointing, particularly with the Governmentrsquos , funded hours policy set to be implemented next year.ldquoIn the case of the Mary Poppins Nursery, the owner has highlighted a number of factors that have contributed to their decision to close.ldquoI have written to East Lothian Council about some of these issues.ldquoHowever, there are also wider issues at play here. The nursery sector has been warning the Scottish Government that private nurseries are struggling in the run-up to the roll-out of its flagship , policy from August .ldquoMinisters must act quickly to address the sectorrsquos concerns and ensure that the capacity exists to deliver the funded hours next year.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoIt is, of course, concerning to hear of any nursery considering closure, and the obvious effects this might have on staff, parents and children.ldquoEast Lothian Council has provided assurance that they will support families to find alternative early learning and childcare places for children who had been expecting to use the Mary Poppins Nursery from this August.Ms Dewar added: ldquoI am distraught that circumstances have forced me to this decision and that such a wonderful place for children to experience their early years is to close.The decision was met with an outpouring of grief on social media.The nurseryrsquos recent th birthday was marked with a garden party.The nursery was founded by Sue Armstrong, affectionately still called lsquoMiss Suersquo, after she had written to Mary Poppins author P L Travers to askshe could use the name.Miss Sue said: ldquoI received many letters from P L Travers about the nursery.ldquoAt the beginning, she wanted to know what the nursery was going to be like. She had no objection to me using the name, she just wanted to find out more. I ended up meeting her as well.ldquoWe were hoping to get her to come and open the nursery  years ago, but her arthritis was bad. We stayed in touch, however. I would send her letters about how the nursery was getting on along with photos, and she would write back saying how she liked it, and ideas of what to do.ldquoShe said that the children should be encouraged to make up their own stories. lsquoChildren like doing that,rsquo she said.Miss Sue sold the nursery to Ms Dewar in  as she was ldquosick of all the paperwork.She said. ldquoWhen I heard it was to close down, well, itrsquos just all so sad really. Itrsquos such a terrible shame.ldquoIt is such a nice and happy place for the children, homely and warm. Itrsquos just awful that it canrsquot stay open.Miss Sue still attends events at the nursery, dressed as the iconic nanny Mary Poppins.She added: ldquoIn the film, Mary Poppins says that shersquoll stay until the winds change. Well, maybe this is the wind changing for Mary Poppins Nursery.Ward councillor Craig Hoy said: ldquoThe closure of the Mary Poppins Nursery is deeply regrettable but reflects the real pressures the independent sector is experiencing as a result of the SNPrsquos , hours policy."The Government faces huge problems to provide the free childcare it has promised. In many areas the level of nursery provision simply isnrsquot there and independent nurseries are already struggling financially with the planned expansion.

title: call-for-double-yellow-lines-at-busy-haddington-junction
story: Parked vehicles regularly line Hopetoun Drive and Rab Moran, from the townrsquos community council, called for double yellow lines to be put down near the streetrsquos junction with Hope Park.Mr Moran repeated his plea for action to be taken to solve the problem at the grouprsquos latest meeting.He said: ldquoI see somebody wrote into the Courier saying it was a tricky junction and I mentioned that as well.ldquoWhen you come round the corner it is like a brick wallsomebody is coming round to meet you.The community councillor stressed that Tustain Motors, which is based on the corner of Hopetoun Drive, was not to blame for the issue and it was simply a busy street.Mr Moranrsquos concerns were echoed by fellow community councillor Jack Worden, who agreed something needed to be done at the junction.

title: newhailes-house-added-to-new-outlander-locations-map
story: The th-century Palladian villa joins Beecraigs Country Park in West Lothian and Arniston House in Midlothian as three of eight new locations that feature in the fourth season of the time-travelling romantic television adventure series starring Caitriona Balfe and Sam Heughan.The Outlander map, created by the national tourism organisation, has been revamped to include more details, including postcodes and whether the on-screen locations feature parking, toilet facilities, admission fees and eateries.Newhailes, owned by the National Trust for Scotland, served as Governor Tyronrsquos home in North Carolina.Outlander locations are popular with visitors and the map now features  of the Scottish locations used in the hit Sony Pictures television show for fans to explore.Outlander follows the romantic adventures of English Second World War combat nurse Claire Randall, who travels back in time to th-century Scotland, where she meets and falls in love with Scottish Highlander Jamie Fraser.Find out more about the interactive online Outlander map at visitscotland outlander, while a printed version is available from select VisitScotland iCentres and featured locations.

title: re-opening-of-haddingtons-swimming-pool-is-delayed-a-month
story: The pool at the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre closed on April  as part of a nine-week refurbishment.However, enjoyleisure, which manages the sports centre, off the townrsquos Mill Wynd, confirmed that the pool would not re-open on Tuesday as planned.Instead, the opening date has been pushed back a month to July .Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, said: ldquoWhilst we are extremely disappointed with the delay, we remain extremely excited about the enhancements and improvements being provided for our customers.ldquoThese works will transform the swimming pool environment at Aubigny into a more modern and dynamic setting aimed at motivating and encouraging more people to get more active more often.ldquoAlthough the dry side facilities remain open at Aubigny, this extended closure of the swimming pool is not what anyone would wish.ldquoenjoy would welcome all our customers at any of our other swimming pools, which remain open.An email was sent out to enjoyleisure members which highlighted the problems.Tom Reid, head of infrastructure at East Lothian Council, echoed Mr Axonrsquos disappointment.He said: ldquoEveryone is looking forward to the completion of this renovation, which will transform the look of the pool for the benefit of the many people who use this much-loved facility.ldquoWe are disappointed that, due to a supply chain issue outwith our control, the date for the poolrsquos re-opening has been now been revised from the end of June with a new opening date of July .ldquoWe appreciate this will be frustrating for pool users who will be eagerly anticipating the poolrsquos re-opening and we are grateful for their patience and understanding.ldquoIrsquod like to assure everyone that we are working very closely with the contractor, subcontractor and enjoyleisure to complete the project within this revised timeframe.The pool hall dates back to the s, with the refurbishment plans including the complete replacement of custom-fit ceiling window  and a new roof covering.Both pools ndash the four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool ndash were to be drained, with a new light ceiling covering replacing the wood cladding.A new energy-efficient lighting scheme is also to be fitted, which it is hoped will transform the look and feel of the facility.Existing wall tiles will be replaced with wall liner .The delay also means the pool will not be open ahead of the school summer holidays starting next Friday .While the pool and health suite are closed, the rest of the centre, including the gym, dance studio, sports hall and cafe, remain open.Ward councillor Craig Hoy said: ldquoThe delay to the reopening of the Aubigny Sports Centre swimming pool will clearly be disappointing for local residents hoping to use the facilities over the school holidays.ldquoI hope East Lothian Council continues to work closely with the contractors and enjoyleisure to ensure there are no further delays.ldquoThe renovation is very welcome, but as the Haddington population grows we still need to explore how to further enhance and expand our leisure and sporting facilities to ensure they remain on a level with those available where in the county and beyond.

title: oor-wullie-sculpture-arrives-in-east-lothian
story: A total of  sculptures capturing Scotlandrsquos favourite scamp are scattered across a nationwide arts trail for  weeks for charity.And the Scottish Seabird Centre in North Berwick has given one of them a home for the next three months.Seabird Spotting Wullie is sponsored by the Jess Mackie Memorial Fund and all donations made on its behalf go to Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity.The memorial fund, set up in memory of Gullane schoolgirl Jess, who died last year, raises money to support music therapy at the hospital.The sculpture was painted by artist Hannah Sanguinetti and features Oor Wullie pretending to be a sea clf, with seabirds sitting on him. Written on the back of his bucket are lists of the types of seabirds and marine le which can be spotted locally.The  Oor Wullie BIG Bucket Trail builds on the success of a similar trail in Dundee three years ago which raised nearly pound,.This time round, sculptures of the national treasure will be seen on the streets of Edinburgh, Glasgow, Aberdeen, Dundee, Inverness and surrounding communities.DC Thomson, which has published Oor Wullie cartoon strips and Christmas annuals featuring the character and his family since the late s, has teamed up with three childrenrsquos hospital charities to share funds raised by the latest trail: Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity, ARCHIE Foundation and Glasgow Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity.Primary schools have also been able to get involved, with a number receiving miniature sculptures of their own to decorate. The results are being put on display around Edinburgh at locations including the National Portrait Gallery, Museum of Childhood and Ocean Terminal.Charlotte Bray, fundraising manager at the Seabird Centre, said: ldquoAs a marine conservation charity the design was spot on and is a fun representation of the local wildle.ldquoThe Jess Mackie Memorial Fund have sponsored the sculpture, which gives it a special relevance for the local community.ldquoJess was a pupil at North Berwick High School and her family have done an incredible job of fundraising for ECHC in her memory.ldquoWe are very happy to be involved in such an exciting nationwide art trail.The trail has been organised in association with Wild in Art and supported by DC Thomson Media.The sculptures were officially unveiled on Monday and will remain until the end of August.A mobile app can be downloaded, with people encouraged to take on each or all of the trails recording each sculpture as they come across it. It also shows a map of each trail and where the sculptures can be found. See oorwullie

title: tims-tales-an-expedition-to-hailes-castle
story: IN DAYS gone by, when most people had to walk from place to place, our sense of distance was more acute.These days we speed by in a car or bus and donrsquot really appreciate just how far we are travelling. Five minutes in a car can cover a distance which would represent a fairly long walk.Itrsquos kind of a simple principle, I know, but one I sometimes forget, as I did a couple of weekends ago. We set off from an event at Amisfield Walled Garden for a walk. My idea was to walk along the River Tyne to Hailes Castle and thenndash by car a -minute round trip.We had some supplies in the form of fruit in my bag and a little water. It was a sunny and warm day and so we set off on our adventure.We began the walk at the old Abbey Bridge which spans the Tyne close to Amisfield. As you walk under its ancient ribbed arches of this late medieval bridge, you get a real sense of its age and the beauty of its construction.The path beyond follows the river and it is almost impossible now to imagine that a great abbey once stood here, with connections to the infant Mary Queen of Scots. A ruined old mill of later centuries still stands here. I reflected on the stories of this location: a courageous nun who defied a flood in the th century and a gruesome murder in the th century and just visible in the near distance the old graveyard, now ringed with trees and almost unrecognisable as a resting place for the dead.A labourer once thought he saw a ghost at the graveyard, but it proved to be something , and I had a wry smile at that tale of a drunken evening over  years ago. These are all tales I have already told here, but they entered my head as we wandered to the gate that led along the northern bank of the river.Hailes Castle is on the southern bank of the river and I knew that there was a bridge that would takes us over. So we set off to find the bridge.But it took us over four hours.It was a stunning walk, with wild flowers and trees decorating the riverbank almost all the way. A grey heron seemed to follow us perhaps he was warning us that the walk was longer than Irsquod anticipated.It is a walk decorated with history too, of course. A stone in the corner of the field by the first gate caught my eye. Deeply ingrained groove marks on it intrigued me. I was later told that it could be the marks of a plough, as the tips of the plough have scraped over the stone a ploughman unwittingly leaving evidence of his unrecorded toil.Halfway along the walk we arrived at the small hamlet of Sandyrsquos Mill. The cottages and mill itself have been beautully restored. The th-century mill still has its waterwheel, although itrsquos now embedded in silt. The mill ceased working  years ago and was transformed into a residential property, but with much of the old machinery inside still intact. It appears to be a very sympathetic and sensitive restoration.It was beyond Sandyrsquos Mill that the distance began to take its toll. The young kids were tired and desperately looking for the bridge. I spotted Traprain Law some distance away and realised that I had badly misjudged the distance and time it would take with wee ones. We had to sit and have a rest and story, with that grey heron listening, to gather the energy to continue.The kids didnrsquot complain much as we wandered along the still-beautul path, now desperately looking for the bridge. As we had rested wersquod phoned for friends to come and lsquorescuersquo us at Hailes Castle with chocolate and water, and we knew they were there waiting for us.Irsquove never been quite so pleased to see Hailes Castle. It loomed suddenly from across the river. I had never approached it from this direction and it certainly did its best to impress. The bridge was just a wee way further and we finally crossed it with a sense of relief.When we arrived at the castle, the kids devoured the chocolate and water, in a way that reminded me of a scene in the movie Ice Cold in Alex. Thank goodness for good friends.Wersquod made it and what a sense of adventure ndash and an achievement!I sat with the kids and told stories as my we went with the friends to retrieve our car. Hailes Castle drips with history but they wanted tales about giants.The day was a lesson for me: to think more carefully about distance when setting on a walk! I thoroughly recommend the path, especially on a lovely summerrsquos day. But itrsquos going to take half a dayyou have kids. So prepare for that!Unbelievably, the kids later wanted to go to a playpark. ldquoWhere do they get the energy  my we asked.ldquoFrom us! I replied!

title: hopes-of-seeing-railway-station-return-to-haddington
story: RAGESmet with Peter Brett Associates ndash a leading consultancy of engineers and planners ndash to outline the case for improved transports links to and from East Lothian.One of the more ambitious plans was to see theof a railway station to Haddington.Residents of the town have not been served by a railway station since , with the station closing to freight nearly  years later.However, RAGES feels there could still be a possibility of a station ing to the town ndash though the group acknowledged that work needed to be done.A spokesman for the group said: ldquoRAGES expressed its preference for re-opening of the Haddington branch, ideally to the previous terminus on Station Road.ldquoMinimal compulsory purchase relocation of existing industrial units would be required the biggest physical obstacle would be the reconstruction of the A overbridge which was unwisely built without preserving the railway alignment and loading gauge.ldquoA level crossing would be required at Gateside, failing which an alternative road access could be provided for the new houses on the north side of the line onto the A.There was also a suggestion of creating car parking and even a park and ride facility in the town to serve the new service, which would link the town with Edinburgh.The spokesman added: ldquoAs insufficient parking exists at Station Road , a park and ride station at Oak Tree would be essential, which could also serve the substantial Letham Mains and Gateside developments.ldquoJust east of where the A crosses the railway formation, there is a large rectangular piece of ground, occupied only by scrub, which would be suitable as a car park.ldquoAs only single track would suffice between Longniddry and Haddington, it would be possible to retain a footpath cycleway as the line was originally provided with double track throughout.ldquoAn electric train service from Haddington to Edinburgh would provide the speed and capacity which road transport ndash car or bus ndash cannot match. Frequency should be half-hourly.Councillor Tom Trotter, who represents Haddington, backed the station bid.He said: ldquoIt is a good idea, especially with the town expanding as it is.ldquoIt would be a tremendous asset to have.However, the councillor felt it was more likely the station would have to find a new site, such as Alderston, to the north of the town.He added: ldquoIn the short-term it is unrealistic, but hopefully in the longer term things can be put in place to make it a realistic possibility.ldquoIt is a great idea and Irsquom sure it would get support from all the local ward councillors, but where it would go and how much it would cost are questions.

title: preview-prestonpans-gala-2019
story: This year is the th anniversary of Prestonpans Childrenrsquos Gala.On gala day itself, the festivities kick off with the crowning ceremony at am at Prestonpans Community Centre.There is then a fancy-dress competition at Middleshot Square at noon before the parade heads off through the town.From Middleshot Square, it heads along Hawthorn Road and down West Loan to the war memorial, then along High Street before turning up Redburn Road, then along North Grange Avenue, where it ends at Mary Murray Park, behind the community centre.The park hosts the gala dayrsquos family fun, which includes a funfair with a host of rides, as well as old favourites such as hook the duck.There is also a vintage fire engine on display, as well as an American police car, motorbike displays, ponies, birds of prey, beat the goalie, Zorbs, safe archery, NERF guns, crazy golf, a tombola and a gala raffle, not to mention ice cream vans, tea and coffee, Mr Donut Man, crepes, waffles, hot dogs, nachos, a burger van, La Favorita pizzas, stalls selling gts, sweets and cake.Gala day marks the beginning, not the end of Prestonpansrsquo week of fun and activities.Events are as follows:Saturday, June Monday, June Tuesday, June Wednesday, June Thursday, June Friday, June

title: bid-to-turn-former-rbs-in-north-berwick-into-a-house
story: The townrsquos Royal Bank of Scotlandclosed in June last year. Since then, the building on Westgate has sat empty.But now Mr and Mrs Nigel Sharp are keen to transform the site, with plans to demolish the former bank hall and create a new house with office space. A design statement included with the planning application says that the proposals aim to be ldquorespectful of the character and amenity of the residential area.It reads: ldquoThe proposals seek to interpret these features in a contemporary manner that gives cognisance to the existing Victorian building that it joins on to.ldquoWith the main element built out of high-quality stone, the proposal will fit in very well within the context.Plans show the home on three levels, with a basement, ground floor and first floor.The basement includes a wine cellar, shower room and rumpus room while the ground floor features an en-suite bedroom.Access would also be created to an office on the ground floor, with space for a driveway turntable outside. The first floor has a lounge and kitchenette, plus a second en-suite bedroom.The document continues: ldquoNigel has Parkinsonrsquos disease meaning that the new home will need to be designed to accommodate specic requirements in this regard.ldquoThe floor plan is designed to be accessible at all levels with the provision of a lt and wide hall and doorways.ldquoHeight, light and bright is what is achieved in this scheme along with an element of lsquowowrsquo everywhere one looks.

title: driver-given-asbo-for-his-cars-loud-exhaust
story: Officers were in patrol in Haddington town centre last month when they spotted a vehicle with a modied exhaust.It was deemed to be ldquoexcessively noisy.PC Charlie Duncan told the townrsquos community council: ldquoThe vehicle was stopped and the driver was issued with an anti-social behaviour order and advised to have the exhaust amended accordingly.

title: looking-back-25-years-since-wallyford-railway-station-opened
story: Opened on June , , it now handles about , passengers per year or just under , each week.John Yellowlees, from Prestonpans, a retired ScotRail employee who is now an honorary rail ambassador for the company, was at the opening and has shared his diary entry from the day with Courier readers this week.It read: ldquoThe . Waverley-North Berwick EMUwas specially decorated for opening of Wallyford, where two coal trains passed during speeches by Paul Prescott, David Begg and Chris Green declaring open Railtrack Scotlandrsquos first new station.ldquoThree greyhounds paraded on , then coaches to Sweethope Hotel, sitting next to Oliver Barratt and opposite Councillor John Clford. Spoke also to Andrew Hajducki whose third book will deal with the Edinburgh-Berwick main line.The opening of Wallyford Station was celebrated in the evening at the greyhound track, which was to close a few years later.The station was provisionally known as Musselburgh East but was opened as Wallyford. Funded by Lothian Regional Council, it was opened by its transportation convener David Begg.Also present was Councillor George Wanless from Musselburgh, former chairman of East Lothian District Council, Paul Prescott of Railtrack, and Chris Green, ScotRail.Harry Barker, chairman of East Lothian Community Rail Partnership, said this week: ldquoCommuting to work in Edinburgh has always been a feature of our local transport scene but, unless you lived close to a railway station, the only public transport was by bus, which involved becoming embroiled in the Musselburgh traffic.ldquoFollowing the electrication of the East Coast Mainline to London and, at the same time, the line from Drem to North Berwick, paid for by the local council, East Lothian had for the first time an electric commuter railway. A station at Wallyford became a reality in an effort to reduce car commuting.ldquoWith a journey time of around - minutes to Edinburgh, the station quickly became well used and now has around , passenger movements annually ndash that is nearly , per week.ldquoIts situation became ideal for a park and ride operation attracting car drivers from towns not served by rail such as Tranent and where.Alister Hadden, chairman of Wallyford Community Council, recalled how his we Nancy, who was a local community councillor at the time, attended the opening of the station.He said: ldquoWallyford Railway Station is another great asset and addition to Wallyford, with the numbers using it growing each year.ldquoThey are now in the process of extending the railway  to accommodate the commuters using the service.ldquoThe station has also promoted the park and ride car park which has numerous buses going in and out.ldquoMusselburgh Area Partnership, in partnership with Sustrans, is improving the path network to the station for walkers and cyclists alike, making it very accessible from all directions.ldquoWith so many new houses being built around Wallyford, it is a great asset to have in the village.

title: muirfield-invites-women-to-become-members-for-the-first-time
story: Members of the club voted . per cent in favour of allowing women to become members of the club, near Gullane, in March .That followed a vote the previous year in which not enough members had backed scrapping the clubs men-only policy to force a change,  per cent voting in favour but a  per cent share being required.Subsequently, organisers The RA announced that Muirfield would no longer be a host venue for The Open Championship, which it last hosted in .Now, women, along with three men, have been invited to take up membership from Monday after taking part in the clubrsquos traditional process, which is the same for all members.Alistair Campbell, captain of the Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers, said: ldquoIt is my great pleasure to announce that  women have been formally invited to join the Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers this month."This marks a milestone in the clubrsquos illustrious historyand we look forward to welcoming all of our new members to share in the great values and traditions of our club.ldquoWe are delighted now to have completed the extensive renovation of the clubhouse, which includes improvements to the whole building for the first time since . We now have a clubhouse that matches our world-class golf course.As is the tradition at the club, iniduals who are invited to become members must first be proposed and seconded by existing members and five referees.The clubrsquos membership is then invited to write in support, or otherwise, of those put forward, who are personally known to them or have golfed with them. This process is the same for men and women.Twelve women, two of whom are overseas candidates, have now successfully progressed to this final stage of the approval process. They have now been formally invited to join as members of the Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers.Mr Campbell added: ldquoThis year marks the thanniversary of the clubrsquos first recorded golf competition."We are proud of our clubrsquos rich history but equally excited for its future and the part all of our new members will play in the clubrsquos cherished traditions.

title: bid-for-11-flats-on-car-park-in-haddington
story: A decade ago the former Courier building on the corner of Haddingtonrsquos Market Street and Newton Port was bought by East Lothian Housing Association .ELHA converted the Market Street side of the building into its headquarters while the northern part was turned into  flats called The Granary.Now, the seven-space car park immediately adjacent to The Granary ndash used by residents there but also available to the general public ndash could be turned into  flats and associated car parking.A planning application has been lodged with East Lothian Council by developer Whiteadder Limited.If approved, there would be a total of  car parking spaces for the whole site ndash the new and the old flats.According to a design and access statement, which is included with the planning application, the site is ldquocurrently an unattractive car park which detracts from the town centre setting.It goes on: ldquoGiven the sitersquos location within the Haddington Conservation Area it represents an opportunity to redevelop a brownfield site.ldquoThe design of the new building will respect its historic context and character to create a positive contribution to the area.The ground floor would be home to a two-bedroom flat, with the first and second floors containing four two-bedroom properties and a one-bedroom flat.Outside, there would be a total of  car parking spaces, as well as a cycle store for  bicycles.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, had concerns about the plans.She said: ldquoWe did object to that for the simple reason that although they are providing car parking spaces, the existing cars that park there are going to have nowhere to park.ldquoYou are just adding that onto the congestion in the town.Councillor Tom Trotter, who represents Haddington, acknowledged the removal of general parking spaces could prove an issue.He said: ldquoIf the council came up with a solid idea and created a car park before they started going down the line of losing spaces, it would probably take the edge off the negativity surrounding any development, especially in the town centre. There are major parking issues at the moment. [The council] are trying their best to resolve it but it is just taking time.The car park is owned by ELHA.

title: mystery-of-hidden-signatures-from-1940-solved-from-new-zealand
story: Mikey McKinnon, , who owns McKinnon Decorators, was asked by the owners of the property on Eskview Terrace to strip off old woodchip wallpaper and repaint the walls in the hallway.As he got to work, he found that previous decorators had signed and dated their work, as is tradition in the trade.But Mikey, from Edinburgh, was stunned to see that the signatures were almost  years old ndash and curious about the men behind them.The lettering was feint but legible and said: lsquoPapered by David M Steeples A.R.P,  June, , assisted by Robt N Bannerman, R.A.F, L.D.V.rsquoKeen to seehe could find out more as he had to paint over the signatures, he got in touch with the Courier and we appealed for readersrsquo help for information on the duo.And the mystery was solved by Margaret Paterson, , from the Levenhall area of Musselburgh ndash a friend of Mr Steeplesrsquo daughter Jenny Body, who now lives in New Zealand.She had just ed home from visiting Jenny and was told of the newspaper article by her friends George and Florence Wilson, who live in Musselburgh town centre.Margaret said: ldquoBefore I went, I told them about my trip and who I was visiting.ldquoIf I had not, George would not have known the Steeples name and would not have asked methere was a connection with the newspaper article and photograph of the paintersrsquo signatures.The Steeples family had a shop at the top of Links Street and lived above the shop in front of Musselburgh Congregational Church.Margaret lived across the road at  Links Street and she and Jenny, whom she knew as Janet then, were best friends, both attending Musselburgh Grammar School.ldquoI remember her dad as a man in white overalls who was always busy and then he went into the army, said Margaret.Jenny, , emigrated to New Zealand in .Margaret said: ldquoWe lost touch for a while but met up again when she came on one of her visits home.ldquoMy husband died last August and, when I let Jenny know, she immediately asked me out to New Zealand for a visit, which I did in February.Jenny added: ldquoOur first shop belonged to my grandfather and his brother and was on North High Street opposite where The Brunton is now.ldquoThe building is still there and belonged to my great aunt until the s. The shop moved to the corner of Links Street, which is where I grew up.Mr Steeples served with the Royal Army Service Corps during the Second World War. He died, in his mid-s, in .Jenny said: ldquoI canrsquot remember my dad being in the A.R.P. but he went off to war sometime in  and served in France and Belgium.ldquoHe used to tell me stories about how he and [legendary field marshall] Montgomery won the war between them ndash not entirely believable but I was only about eight!She added: ldquoHe and his brother Jack took over the paint business and, after the war, Jack moved to Forfar and continued painting. We were then D  J Steeples.ldquoMy dad was a very good sign writer. I loved watching him. I used to knit mittens for him to keep his hands warm in winter but leave his fingers free.ldquoHe closed the shop in the late s and semi-retired.A member of the Lodge St John Fisherrow, Mr Steeples was also a keen golfer.Jenny said: ldquoI know the name Bob Bannerman but canrsquot picture him. He could have been one of my fatherrsquos apprentices but I am inclined to think he was a family friend.After her move to New Zealand ldquoin a fit of wanderlust, Jenny lived in Dunedin for about  years before moving to Auckland in the s. She has now retired to Orewa, north of Auckland.An accountant and real estate worker, she met her husband John while she was working in London.She said: ldquoBeing brought up in Fisherrow, the sea was in my blood and I still live close by ndash I have to say the water is a tad warmer here than it ever was in Musselburgh!ldquoI have three children and  grandchildren, none of whom are painters, although I dabble a little bit. Nowadays, I spend my le gardening, which I love, and playing bridge.ldquoI have ed about four times to Musselburgh, staying with a friend in Portobello. Last time was about eight years ago.ldquoI was thrilled to bits to hear about my dadrsquos signature. It is unbelievable after all these years ndash almost  years to the day.Mikey said: ldquoIrsquom really surprised that a family member was tracked down and, given that she is on the other sidethe world, it shows you the power of the local press.ldquoIrsquom happy for her that it bought her some joy to see a memory of her dad. Irsquom sure it would have brought back some nice memories.

title: historic-army-squadron-to-parade-through-dunbar
story: ESquadron of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry will rededicate their memorial at Dunbar Parish Church.They will then be awarded the freedom of the county and will march from Dunbar Leisure Pool next Saturdayat .am.The parade then makes its way along High Street before reaching the Lothians and Border Horse memorial at the church for a special ceremony at am.Captain Alan Hume of the Lothians and Border Yeomanry said: ldquoThis is a seminal moment in the history of the Lothians and Border Yeomanry and our relationship with East Lothian.ldquoSince reforming in , we have grown in capability as light cavalry and reconnected with the East Lothian communities.ldquoReceiving the Freedom of East Lothian will re-establish the golden thread of our heritage, allowing us to write the next chapter in a proud and distinguished history.Dunbar Museum will host an exhibition of military treasures recently ed to the Yeomanry, while the townrsquos Royal British Legion will play host to a family event.At a full meeting of East Lothian Council last month, members unanimously agreed to grant the Freedom of the county to the Lothians and Border Yeomanry.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos Armed Forces champion, will host the civic reception at which the Freedom of East Lothian will be presented to the squadron.The North Berwick Coastal ward member said: ldquoIrsquom delighted that we are recognising the important role that the Lothians and Border Yeomanry played, and continues to play, within East Lothian with this rarely-bestowed honour.ldquoAs a signatory of a national Covenant, this council and our partners have committed to supporting members of armed forces community wherever we can.ldquoThe reception and activities on July  will provide an occasion to reflect upon the part that the Yeomanry, and all our armed services, play in our society.Lothians and Border Yeomanry forms the Edinburgh Squadron of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry, the British Armyrsquos newest combat unit.The squadron takes great pride in continuing the regimental history of the Lothians and Border Horse, which dates from .As a Yeomanry unit, from its inception, the Lothians were manned by locals who continued to live in their communities, much like the current Army Reserve.In dferent incarnations, the regiment saw action throughout the Boer Wars and the First World War.The st Lothians and Border Horse Yeomanry became the first cavalry unit in the British Army to see action during the Second World War in France in , and later became part of the Dunkirk evacuation.Since the foundation of the contemporary squadron in  at Redford Barracks in Edinburgh, the Lothians have again been represented overseas in Kenya and Poland.The Lothians and Border Yeomanry will be the first contemporary military unit awarded the Freedom of East Lothian, and only the second reserve unit in Scotland to be awarded the freedom of any Scottish county after the A Squadron of the Queenrsquos Own Yeomanry ndash which is now A Squadron of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry ndash was awarded the Freedom of South Ayrshire.

title: tims-tales-the-knights-riddle-rule
story: FOR this summer, I will share some tales that contain a riddle or mystery to solve. I have heard many dferent versions of this tale, and most recently come across one version in a book by Taffy Thomas, who is a renowned storyteller. Here is my version of the story, which I have titled lsquoThe Riddle Rulersquo:IT WAS to be the final race of the tournament. The two knights had been equally matched, and now they would race each other for the prize of a gold cup filled with gold coins.There was an air of excitement as the crowds gathered for this race. Sir John and Sir Harry arrived together, each mounted on their stallions. Sir Johnrsquos horse was called Lightning, while Sir Harryrsquos horse was named Spear.They were equally matched, both knights had won an equal amount of races, and both had won against each other. There was no favourite, everyone knew this race would be very close.The atmosphere was electric with anticipation.Then the kingrsquos storyteller leaned over to whisper in the kingrsquos ear: ldquoYour majesty, this race is the last of the tournament. I feel it should be a race with an extra challenge, so that the crowd are better pleased.The king agreed, but asked the storyteller what he thought the extra challenge should be.ldquoThe race should be a test of the knightsrsquo wits as well as their riding ability, replied the storyteller. ldquoSet them a riddle rule and see how they solve it.ldquoAnd what is the riddle rule to be  asked the king.The storyteller smiled: ldquoDeclare the rules of this race to be thus: the horse which crosses the finish line second will win the cup and coins for its owner.And so the king declared the riddle rule just before the beginning of the race: ldquoThe horse which crosses the finish line second will win the cup and gold for its owner.There was a murmuring amongst the spectators. The knights looked at each other, thinking.When the starter flag was lowered and the king cried ldquogo, both knights stayed at the starting line. ldquoYou go first, said Sir John to Sir Harry. ldquoNo, after you, said Sir Harry to Sir John. But neither knight was willing to leave the start line lest they be deemed to be first.Soon there were boos and clapping from the crowd, but the prize was too great for either knight to risk going first.ldquoThis race is no fun, said the king to the storyteller, annoyed now that hersquod agreed to the change in rules.ldquoGive them until this afternoon to find a way to race, replied the storyteller, ldquothere is a way but they must discover it. It will challenge their wits and also their riding skills.And so the king stood: ldquoThe race is postponed until pm this afternoon. The knights must find a way to race to the riddle rule, otherwise the prize will be forfeited.For the rest of the day there was an excited buzz as people began to discuss possible solutions to the riddle rule with the knights.ldquoWhy donrsquot you agree to cross the finish line together  was one suggestionldquoBut then they would be equal first and the prize would be lost, commented another.ldquoBesides, said Sir John, ldquoI do not trust Sir Harry not to pull his horse back at the last moment. ldquoI do not trust you either, said Sir Harry.The deadline was fast approaching and no solution to the riddle rule had been found.ldquoPerhaps being first is more important than winning the gold, said an old woman.The knights looked at each other, thinking about this. Then they both said ldquonaw and shook their heads.It was  minutes before the race and a child came up to the knights and said: ldquoI have an idea. Everyone looked down at the child and laughed. How could a poor child know the answer when the knights themselves and all the spectators were scunnered But the storyteller was walking by and overheard the laughter. ldquoChildrenrsquos wisdom is not to be laughed at, he scolded them.And so the knights asked the child for the solution.The child said two words to the knights.In a flash, the knights got mounted and prepared to race. When the starter flag was lowered and the king shouted ldquogo, both Sir John and Sir Harry raced as fast as they could, each being desperate to be first across the finish line. Their riding skills were well challenged by this race.Who won does not matter in this story. What matters are the two words that were said by the child. They were the answer to the riddle rule, and so made the race possible.What were those two words If you havenrsquot already worked it out then re-read the story carefully. If you still donrsquot know, and want to know the answer, then I will give it next week.Or perhaps you could ask a child. I know some children from P in St Gabrielrsquos Primary School who know the answer to this.

title: plan-to-turn-prestonpans-town-hall-into-a-digital-paradise
story: Prestonpans Community Council is bidding to take control of the High Street venue and turn it into an audio-visual and digital haven.A sub-committee of the community council that was formed when the option for a Community Asset Transferof the Town Hall to the group was first offered has come up with a lsquodigital destinationrsquo concept ndash and garnered positive feedback from the community council.The community council is the only group to have put in a note of interest for the Town Hall, and the sub-committee ndash featuring DJ Johnston Smith, Calum Miller and Professor Roger Bromley ndash has now made public its vision for the building.Their initial idea is to create an audio-visual centre within the Town Hall for gamers and competitions, as well as running educational classes on technology and creating a ldquodigital destination for all with k audio-visual displays, fibreoptic network, high-speed computers, floor space and a cafe.In the subcommittee strategy, the members state: ldquoThe activities which once occupied our Town Hall are not filling it today we need to think creatively to identy new audiences.ldquoAll of the traditional activities can now be accommodated where in our town.ldquoOur Town Hall needs to offer something unique to the community: our challenge is to use our assets to create richer social interactions for all.ldquoWe live in a world where the social networks that helped us advance are increasingly replaced by the digital iety. We are all engaging more online, but the conversations are getting shorter and colder.ldquoThese conversations would be more positive and productivewe could host them in a social context.ldquoWhatrsquos needed is a lsquoFaceFaceBookrsquo where the digital world is used to increase the physical interaction.They have suggested that a large screen cover the back of the building behind the stage that could act as a cinema screen, a digital backdrop to a theatre show and a space for presentations and gaming competitions.Although it is only in the very early stages of planning, the concept was well received by the community council, with member Ferhan Ashiq saying that he was ldquovery impressed with the bold and innovative idea.The community council has the option to either lease or buy the Town Hall from East Lothian Council, and this decision has not been officially made yet but will be the next step that is taken, discussing a business plan and the terms of the transfer with the local authority.The approach is laid out in the strategy, which states that the community council will ldquoreview the best practice from where and arrange research visits to similar facilities. We then refine our idea, seeking feedback from people in Prestonpans. Then we follow the commercial path of least resistance, working with East Lothian Council and other bodies. We bootstrap the idea ASAP with initial funding needed to install the equipment, secure and manage the premise. Then we use the success of the venue to fundraise for improvements and enhancements to the structure of the building to renovate the interior.Brian Weddell, chair of the community council, said: ldquoI was delighted that the feedback from community council members was  per cent positive.ldquoIt is an exciting and imaginative use of a grossly under-used community asset that could help kickstart the revitalisation of Prestonpans High Street.The Town Hall was identied as one of the six viable properties across the county suitable for a CAT, offering local organisations the chance to lease or buy them.

title: work-on-affordable-homes-at-letham-mains-haddington-under-way
story: In total,  new council houses and a further  housing association homes are being built at the Letham Mains site, off the B near Oaktree Junction.The site has a number of dferent developers currently at ious stages of construction as more than  new homes are planed alongside a new primary school on the land.East Lothian Council said that the work on the affordable housing, which was recently awarded to Hart Builders with a total cost of pound.million, was now under way.The homes are expected to be completed in phases between spring and autumn next year, with three more affordable developments expected to start on the Letham Mains site in future years.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, the councilrsquos cabinet spokesperson for housing, said: ldquoThis is great news for current and future residents of East Lothian.ldquoThere is a clear need for new affordable housing developments and these sites at Letham Mains will help contribute to meeting our local housing strategy outcomes by increasing the supply of affordable housing and improving access across dferent tenures and house types.The new Castle Rock Edin will take ownership of the  housing association homes being built on the site.Richard Jennings, the associationrsquos managing director, said: ldquoThere is strong demand for mid-market rent accommodation in East Lothian and we are delighted to deliver an affordable choice of high-quality, well-managed homes for people wishing to be part of the vibrant new community at Letham Mains.

title: preview-3-harbours-festival
story: Residents and visitors alike can enjoy art galleries, live music events, family afternoons with pebble decorating and ukulele orchestras, open houses, cooking demonstrations and workshops over the course of the festival, which runs from Saturday to next Sunday .The festival, which was started more than  years ago, is going from strength to strength, expanding and becoming more erse, with something for everyone in its programme.For the live music fans out there, there is a chance to see the Tom Fairnie Band play their famous Americana music supported by Paul Brown, then Andy Brown, Dropkick and Fuzzystar for the Indie lovers, Alex Hodgson and Rhys Heaven for the folk fans, and to get an eclectic mix all in one sitting, there are the Live on the Lawn sessions, an afternoon of music in the majestic Cockenzie House and Gardens .To keep the young ones and old ones entertained all at once, this year will see a Harbour Family Afternoon added to the programme. Wool spinning, ukulele orchestra, pebble decorating, sign writing and live music will grace Port Seton Harbour as the festival celebrates the communityrsquos links to the sea.This sea celebration continues with the event Putting to Sea that includes intergenerational conversations, songs and stories from those who have lived, worked and put out to sea from Port Seton Harbour.For the foodies out there, the festival has three Tasty Notes events which involve food demonstrations with interesting food concoctions alongside live music, again at Cockenzie House and Gardens.An Arts and Crafts Fair and a Therapy Taster will all be on offer for those looking for new ways to relax body and soul, as well as makers from all over East Lothian showing their work, with kiddie face paints in the gardens and storyteller Tim Porteus taking a childrenrsquos writing and painting workshop.The streets will be lined with buskers, providing a live music soundtrack for those exploring the streets and making their way to venues with many more events and exhibitions to enjoy.Festival organisers Jane Brown and Rebecca Dover have said that this year there is something for everyone at the festival.For a full programme of events for the festival, visit harbours

title: north-berwicks-macdonald-marine-hotel-spa-to-be-sold
story: The Macdonald Marine Hotel  Spa in North Berwick, owned by Macdonald Hotels, is one of  hotels that the company has decided to sell in order to repay in full its current Bank of Scotland debt and invest in its remaining properties.The properties will be sold to a private equity and real estate investor.The hotel chain has pledged that the Marine and the other properties sold will continue to operate as hotels and staff will be retained.Donald Macdonald, the grouprsquos founder and executive chairman, said: ldquoItrsquos been  years since I started the business along with my fellow board members Gerry Smith and Gordon Fraser, and itrsquos been a privilege to have shared such an incredible journey with both of them and with so many other fantastic colleagues.ldquoI am extremely grateful to have led a team of talented and hardworking people who have built such a signicant business, but itrsquos now the right time to move onto the next stage of the journey."The Marine joins many more iconic hotels that the company is letting go of, including the Rusacks Hotel overlooking the th green of the Old Course in St Andrews, the five-star Randolph Hotel in Oxford, the five-star Bath Spa, and the Compleat Angler, located on the banks of the River Thames in Marlow.Mr Macdonald added: ldquoThe board carefully weighed up all the proposals and unanimously agreed that selling the majority of the hotels to a new, well-funded investor will enable them to realise their full potential, both as hotels and in terms of the signicant development potential on several of the sites.ldquoThis is excellent news for the , loyal employees based at these hotels, their  colleagues in our central support team and also for our valued customers and suppliers.ldquoIrsquom hugely grateful to every one of our staff for their continued contribution and dedication to the business. We never lose sight of the fact that we can only provide great service to our guests through a talented and valued workforce.ldquoThroughout this process, potential investors have regularly commented on both the strength of our management team and the dedication of our staff, and this deal will give them a superb future.The company will still retain  of its hotels across the UK and Spain.The sale is due to go through at the end of August to an undisclosed sum.

title: mid-air-drama-for-musselburgh-family-as-bird-strike-delays-holiday
story: The TUI flight to the Canary Islands that the family were on took off from Edinburgh Airport last Thursday morning but was erted to land at Glasgow Airport after the plane was hit by a bird.Author Alex Brown, , who owns Ideal Flooring Solutions and the Bronx Boxing Gym in Tranent, and we Monica, , who live on Edinburgh Road, were onboard along with their son Zander, daughter-in-law Denise, both , and grandchildren Evie, five, and Jude, three, of Clayknowes Way.Mr Brown, whose comic crime thriller Hit Me is being considered as a movie, told the Courier: ldquoIt was a bit scary for all involved but everyone was happy to be safe and on the ground.The plane took off from Edinburgh at .am and was set to arrive in Lanzarote at .am local time.Mr Brown said: ldquoWe heard a crunching sound and were then told  minutes later that we had to land at Glasgow Airport.ldquoWe landed around am and all the emergency services met the aircraft on the runway.ldquoThe pilot told us a bird had hit an engine and the aircraft had been damaged.ldquoWe all got a pound voucher which paid for a meal which was given to us in Glasgow not long after we landed.ldquoWe were told it would be a good few hours before a replacement aircraft would arrive and we may even have to go to a hotel for the night.ldquoThankfully, a plane arrived around .pm.ldquoThe staff were all very good and helpful. There were lots of children on the plane and they never really knew what was going on.ldquoWith us all knowing there was an issue with the original flight, we were all just happy to land in Glasgow.ldquoWe finally arrived at our hotel at midnight. This was  hours later than we should have arrived.ldquoThe delay seemed not to bother us too much. My grandchildren took it in their stride and behaved amazingly.He added: ldquoSo it was very close to a -hour delay and we missed a day of our holiday.ldquoMany passengers had come from Glasgow to get the early am flight from Edinburgh so as to make the most of their first day, only to end up back in Glasgow and get to the hotel  hours after the original flight left.A TUI UK spokesperson said: ldquoWe would like to apologise to customers on board flight TOM from Edinburgh to Lanzarote, which erted to Glasgow due to the aircraft suffering a bird strike.ldquoWe understand how frustrating delays can be and we would like to thank customers for their patience.ldquoThe safety and wellbeing of our passengers and crew is our highest priority.

title: preview-haddington-show-2019
story: FARMING and agriculture has been intrinsic to the Scottish way of le since the first settlers cultivated the fertile lands, providing food for communities and, later, produce to trade with.Celebrating the traditions of working the land has become embedded into Scotlandrsquos rich heritage ndash and agricultural shows still reflect that historic link between farming and the community.The annual Haddington Agricultural Show is one of Scotlandrsquos oldest events, dating from . Itrsquos a testament to the continued interest in local heritage and tradition that it is as relevant in  as it was two centuries ago.Now in its th year, the annual Haddington Show will open its gates on Saturday to the crowds and showcase the finest producers, breeders and vendors from East Lothian.The show is a signicant event within the area, with traditional displays of animals, produce and crafts but also offering entertainment and attractions that appeal to contemporary audiences.Of course there is always the lsquoBest in Breedrsquo awards, where competition is fierce but friendly between cattle and sheep breeders, and judging is a serious affair.There are about  horse classes, from veteran riders to the horse and rider fancy dress. The number of entrants reflect the unmistakable popularity of equestrian pursuits within East Lothian.And for those who prefer more craft-based endeavours, there are numerous prizes for the craft schedules, including floristry, baking, stick dressing, photography and jam-making. Itrsquos certainly an inclusive event.Therersquos even a hugely popular vintage farm machinery section, a huge draw for farming and non-farming visitors alike and which makes an impressive vista across the showground.Butyou think itrsquos all about prize turnips and tractors, yoursquod be wrong. Such is the reputation of the Haddington Show it attracts some prestigious performers.One of the most sought-after tickets is for the remarkable pop-up opera shows: a touring version of Scottish Opera who perform in a mobile lorry, complete with seating and stage. Theyrsquoll be singing highlights from three operas during the show and tickets are on a first-come first-served basis on the day.Other notable entertainment is from the Broke FMX stunt motorbike team. Theyrsquoll be performing acrobatic stunts that will have the audience holding their breath as the UKrsquos top ranked freestyle motocross riders reach heights of  feet and jump gaps of almost  feet.For something a little less heart-stopping but no less thrilling, donrsquot miss The Drakes of Hazard. Marvel at the skill of Mark Wylie with his sheepdog and Indian runner duck display team as they navigate around obstacles, working in harmony ndash a lsquomust seersquo for the kids.And no Scottish agricultural show would be complete without a pipe band.The Haddington Show is pleased to welcome East Lothianrsquos own Haddington Pipe Band, a befitting soundtrack to this traditional event.Asall that entertainment isnrsquot enough, visitors can also sample and buy a range of locally produced goods in the East Lothian Producers Marquee. The very best produce from our area includes locally made oils, dairy goods, bread, spices and, of course, whisky!Another area not to be missed is the equally local Craft and Lestyle Marquee, where you can buy items made in East Lothian. Again, the choice is ied, definitely a lsquosomething for everyonersquo scenario and some unusual offerings like hand-knitted kidsrsquo clothing, candles, accessories madefrom feathers, tweed items and furniture ndash and thatrsquos just the edit! Throughout the year, they work tirelessly, and largely voluntary, to make the show a success. Co-ordinating the events, booking the entertainment and physically preparing the ground for the big day takes a huge effort. Itrsquos all worthwhile to uphold the important heritage of East Lothian and its agricultural traditions.Some visitor information: the show ground will be serviced by a free shuttle bus from Dunbar and Haddingtonand therersquos plenty of parking.Gates open at am until pm on Saturday.
